subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content:
For some health care industry watchers, it‚Äôs no surprise at all that Amazon Care is going away as a stand-alone entity.


VIEW IN BROWSER
 | SUBSCRIBE




BUILD OR BUYTHE SHUTDOWN OF AMAZON CARE IS AN IMPORTANT LESSON IN DISRUPTION
Chalk up another failure in health care for Amazon, one of the ultimate market disruptors.¬† First, its much-hyped effort with JPMorgan and Berkshire Hathaway to reform health care, Haven, ended its short life.¬†
 Now, Amazon Care, its effort to tackle telemedicine and primary care for the employer market on a national basis ‚Äì which Amazon itself trumpeted as gaining more and more clients ‚Äì is being shut down.
 Is that all the proof we needed of what many people have said over the years: health care is just harder to disrupt than most industries?¬†

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content: Maybe not.

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content:
The shutdown of Amazon Care may come back to a simple choice that companies, especially those with a lot of cash, have to make when it comes to breaking into new markets: build or buy.¬†
 For some health care industry watchers, it‚Äôs no surprise at all that Amazon Care is going away as a stand-alone entity. When Amazon made the decision in July to acquire primary care company One Medical, which does what Amazon Care wanted to do, it was the writing on the wall that something was going to change.¬†
 And for a cash-rich company looking for opportunities to buy into a stock market that had pushed down the value of recently public health companies ‚Äì One Medical had traded as high as $58 in 2021 and Amazon bought it for $18 a share ‚Äì Amazon may have been more opportunistic than anything else in staking the next stage of its future in health care on One Medical.¬† ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not surprising they‚Äôre shutting it down,‚Äù said Sari Kaganoff, general manager of consulting at Rock Health, which invests as a VC in health start-ups and has a health advisory and research arm.

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content: ‚ÄúTheir vision always was to have a primary care integrated solution and now it will have a better solution than what they could build,‚Äù Kaganoff said.¬†

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content: It was a little surprising, maybe, that Amazon announced the shutdown before the One Medical deal even closed, but One Medical has many more markets, many more offices and many more companies that are clients than Amazon ever did (it had to boast about signing up Whole Foods, which it owns, as a client for Amazon Care). Maybe also surprising: it didn‚Äôt wait to rebrand One Medical as Amazon Care.

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content:
PillPack, its acquisition in the pharmacy space, held on for a few years before ultimately becoming Amazon Pharmacy.
¬†
 By Amazon‚Äôs own account, it was a failure, at least in the terms conveyed in the internal memo provided to the press about the shuttering. There's no doubt it struggled with the problem of building up an in-person care component. While telemedicine is a nice have, it‚Äôs not a full health-care solution, and Amazon would have had to ramp up investment considerably to build a true national hybrid health-care practice with sites and physicians and clinics.
¬† In the end, let‚Äôs say Amazon Care was a test run for a business, and once Amazon learned enough to know what it wanted in the long-term, it bought the better company at a time when its value was depressed.¬†
 ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think they failed, because One Medical is great,‚Äù Kaganoff said. ‚ÄúAmazon Care was no different than any other stand-alone health startup in terms of needing to be consolidated,‚Äù adding that, ‚ÄúThey played around with it a bit.‚Äù¬†

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content:
Though past Disruptor 50 lists included companies focused on Amazon Care's original aim, telemedicine, this year's list showed companies focused on tackling much more precise health-care challenges, such as kidney care, diabetes, clinical trial enrollment and pharmacy infrastructure.¬†
 Still, there was at least one direct link to the history of our annual Disruptor 50 list, as well as a potential casualty in the Amazon Care news: two weeks ago the juggernaut signed a deal with Headspace Health, a 2013 Disruptor 50 company, for mental health care services.¬†
 While Amazon‚Äôs healthcare efforts in recent years have been associated with direct battles (i.e., Amazon Care vs. Teladoc), Wall Street analysts have said the market should worry more about Amazon making a string of acquisitions that speak to broader aims.

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content: That seems to still be happening.¬†

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content:
Amazon doesn‚Äôt seem to be done yet pushing its cash around in buying more in health-care, with it in recent headlines as reportedly among bidders for Signify Health, which has an overlap with the Iora Health business of One Medical, focused on a more complicated, Medicare-centric market than standard national care practices.
¬†
 Between One Medical and Signify Health, it‚Äôs clear Amazon still plans to be a formidable player in the health-care space. It can leverage its ability to personalize its offerings, connect to its pharmacy, and ultimately pose a threat to many other retail giants aiming to upend healthcare. Walmart acquired telehealth company MeMD in 2021; CVS, which already offers telemedicine through a deal with Amwell, is another rumored bidder for Signify; and Walgreens has VillageMD and is opening up hundreds of offices in markets around the country.
¬† That retail disruption is only going to grow, for a simple reason: When you look at the share of wallet of everyone, from consumers to employers, the health-care market is a big part of spending. Amazon is already in almost every other chunk of the wallet, except maybe banking (though it has credit cards).¬† What‚Äôs the big chunk of the market they are not in?¬†

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content:
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs healthcare, and they already have so many things consumer-health oriented, it just makes sense to go big in health care,‚Äù Kaganoff said.¬†
 When Haven debuted to much fanfare, people thought the combined might of Berkshire Hathaway, JPMorgan and Amazon could result in a significant driving down of costs throughout the health-care system that Warren Buffett has called a tapeworm on the national economy.

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content: But it‚Äôs as much about something else for Amazon and its rivals.¬†

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content: ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs just market share,‚Äù Kaganoff said.¬†

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content:
As Amazon moves from primary care, into more complicated care, and potentially even chronic care ‚Äì and combines pharmacy and over-the-counter medication with all its offerings ‚Äì everyone from private health start-ups to Teladoc to retail competitors and health-care incumbents should continue to worry. Amazon Care‚Äôs failure may have come at a cost and may not have been messageD as elegantly as Amazon wanted, but what it ultimately is buying and building off may make it the stronger disruptor.
¬†

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content:
Eric Rosenbaum | Senior Editor, CNBC
 @erprose








‚Ää







‚ÄäDISRUPTION IN ACTION
THE REST OF THIS WEEK'S HEADLINES
Analysts encouraged by Snowflake's "exceptionally good" resultsRANKED NO. 40 ON THE 2020 LIST¬†
Shares of Snowflake jumped 20% a day after the company released second-quarter results that beat on the top line. Analysts from Canaccord Genuity said this was ‚Äúanother excellent quarter‚Äù for Snowflake, and though they said executives offered a little caution about the uncertain macroeconomic environment, it seems like business as usual at the company. 

READ MORE
‚ÄäPeloton strikes a deal to sell fitness equipment and apparel on Amazon
TWO-TIME DISRUPTOR 50 COMPANY
Peloton has struck a partnership with Amazon in a bid to broaden its customer base and win back investors‚Äô confidence, as revenue growth slows from pandemic highs and its stock price plunges. In its first foray outside of its core direct-to-consumer business, Peloton will be hawking a selection of its connected-fitness equipment and accessories on Amazon‚Äôs website in the U.S.

READ MORE
‚ÄäCoinbase CEO says crypto exchange has ongoing plans to cut costs and is actively engaged with regulators¬†
THREE-TIME DISRUPTOR 50 COMPANY
Coinbase shares have lost more than 70% of their value this year as the company has grappled with a ‚Äúcrypto winter‚Äù tied to the plummeting of bitcoin and ethereum. Coinbase is facing inflationary pressures and a potential recession, but Armstrong said the macro environment is reminiscent of what the company has dealt with in the past.

subject: Was Amazon Care a failure?
content:
READ MORE
‚Ää‚Ää
WHERE ARE THEY NOW?LOOKING BACK AT THE INAUGURAL LIST, 10 YEARS LATER... THIS WEEK: TWITTER
Today, Twitter is ubiquitous ‚Äî it says it has more than 200 million active daily users and the content published on its platform undeniably shapes culture, politics, and popular discourse across the world.¬†
 But in 2006, Twitter was nothing more than a rough idea from then-New York University student Jack Dorsey. Dorsey, who was working at the podcasting startup Oedo at the time, pitched the idea to his colleagues of creating an SMS service that would allow users to publicly communicate with an entire community, rather than privately to one person, like traditional messaging.¬†
 The idea resonated with the Odeo team, and was then further developed by Dorsey and Noah Glass. A year in, Odeo founder Evan Williams told investors that the startup was pivoting its focus to Twitter, rather than podcasting, and hoping to save investors a loss, offered to buy back Odeo's stock.¬†
 Investors have¬†since speculated¬†if Williams knew more about Twitter's potential than he let on at the time, but nonetheless, they agreed.¬†
 At first, Twitter attracted little attention, but after the team attended the 2007 South by Southwest Interactive conference, where they recieved broad praises, the platform's usage tripled overnight ‚Äî and Twitter established itself as a leading force in the emerging social media landscape.¬†
 Since then, discouraging earnings and an ongoing legal battle has not helped the already skittish state of platform advertisers, who have historically generated most of Twitter's revenue but have decreased spending amid recent economic uncertainty.

READ MORE
‚Ää








‚ÄäONE MORE THING...
 THE FUTURE OF THE CEO JOB IS BECOMING MORE TECHIEWhen it comes to choosing a new CEO, recent history suggests that most companies pick from a small pool.¬†
 Over the past 20 years, 85% of newly named S&P 500 company CEOs came from four roles: chief operating officer, divisional CEO, chief financial officer, or a second-layer management position leading a large business unit, according to¬†data¬†from executive search consulting firm Spencer Stuart.¬†
 But as the importance of staying ahead of the curve on technology and at the forefront of digital transformation has increased since the start of the pandemic, recent appointments suggest companies are starting to look at technology leaders as potential chief executives.

content: We so often talk about the disadvantages women have when it comes to operating in the world compared to their male counterparts√¢‚Ç¨‚Äùthere√¢‚Ç¨‚Ñ¢s the pay gap, the wealth gap, the disparity in caregiving responsibilities√¢‚Ç¨‚Äùbut today, I want to highlight a story on one very important advantage women do have, particularly when it comes to retirement: maintaining close friendships. Recent research shows us that 98% of women report having a best friend, compared with only 85% of men, and that friendships between men are significantly less close than those found between women. As Forbes senior contributor Joseph Coughlin notes in his new piece on the subject

 Welcome to part four (maybe my favorite!) of our six-part series on kickstarting and scaling a consumer business. At this point, you have your startup idea

content: In this post, we bring it all together to go find your first 1,000 users.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Build your growth engine
The big question we‚Äôll be answering in today‚Äôs post: How do you find and acquire your first 1,000 users? 
 This post is an updated and fully revised take on my previous post on this subject

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: [https://substack.com/redirect/3efac75a-ebb6-4587-a732-76c50dadd6ae?u@394114] (my single most popular post of all time).

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Again, an important disclaimer: following these steps does not guarantee success‚Äîbut I‚Äôm confident it will increase your odds.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Let‚Äôs get into it.
 Should I try to get press?

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Run Facebook ads? Find email addresses and cold-email people?

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Where should I start, and what‚Äôs worth my time?
 Let‚Äôs get right to it. After reviewing the early growth strategies of more than 100 consumer companies, it turns out that there are really only seven reliable ways to find your first 1,000 users:
Reach out to friends and colleagues
Reach out to targeted strangers
Go where your target audience hangs out (online or offline)
Enlist influencers (paid or organically)
Get press
Create viral content
Get physical placement (e.g. flyers, stickers, signs)
You can think of this list as a menu of options for kickstarting your product‚Äôs growth:
On occasion, a startup finds success with something ‚Äúoff menu,‚Äù and at the end of this post I‚Äôm including examples of that for completeness and inspiration. However, the core seven strategies account for 99% of all B2C startups‚Äô early growth.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Like with a menu, your job is to peruse this list, pick two or three items that seem appetizing, and try them. If something works, chow down. If not, try something else.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Note, almost every startup finds the vast majority of their early growth from just one or two channels. Some see all of their early growth come from just a single channel (e.g. Udemy and PR, Etsy and online and offline communities, Twitter and influencers).

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
So my advice is to focus. Don‚Äôt order everything on the menu.
 How do you decide which tactic to pursue?
To make your decision even easier, here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve found to be the three common archetypes of early startup growth:
Typical path to first 1,000 users for consumer startups:
Reach out to friends and colleagues (e.g. email them, post on social media, call them)
Go where your target audience hangs out, online or offline (e.g. forums, Product Hunt, college campuses, Craigslist, etc.)
 Enlist influencers
If you‚Äôre a marketplace or platform (e.g. DoorDash, Cameo, Substack):
Reach out to targeted strangers (e.g. DM celebs, email owners)
Get physical placement (e.g. stickers, flyers)
Enable your supply to drive your demand
If you have a remarkable story to tell (e.g. Airbnb, Spotify, Superhuman):
Get press
Try to create viral content
Below I‚Äôll share dozens of stories from founders pursuing each of these tactics, but broadly, here‚Äôs a summary of which tactics were most impactful for all of the largest consumer tech companies:
Thank you to Alexa Mateen Abdi [https://substack.com/redirect/cb095926-106b-4e0e-92d8-26cf83a605e8?u@394114] and Jonathan Badeen [https://substack.com/redirect/efc8e464-82b4-4c44-911c-fde0945cd6a6?u@394114] (Tinder) Alyssa Ravasio [https://substack.com/redirect/8c01e982-e19b-4851-bb51-44498ba31782?u@394114] (Hipcamp), Andrew Chen [https://substack.com/redirect/4345e607-8ee3-4b17-a7ca-f39648733ed2?u@394114] (Uber), Casey Winters [https://substack.com/redirect/7180539c-3996-4038-a146-62a6d054c2d3?u@394114] (Grubhub), Cem Kansu [https://substack.com/redirect/88f255e2-9b98-4cac-9044-c9e26c9cd6b7?u@394114] (Duolingo), Devon Townsend [https://substack.com/redirect/6f930e4b-5ae0-4ebf-a021-4d9b1f497ead?u@394114] (Cameo), Emily Castor Warren [https://substack.com/redirect/4b23e88f-79a5-4c31-98d4-a7be85e30ace?u@394114] (Lyft), Evan Moore [https://substack.com/redirect/2302ccfe-4c5d-45f8-b018-324c625aa9af?u@394114] (DoorDash), Gagan Biyani [https://substack.com/redirect/b3d8f312-048f-42f3-92a6-7582ecdd4dd2?u@394114] (Udemy), Georg Bauser [https://substack.com/redirect/59cc8d11-e61e-4884-98f9-0da51950e5b4?u@394114] (Airbnb), Gilad Horev [https://substack.com/redirect/40f0176d-4726-4f6b-89cb-2f4cb92f6824?u@394114] (Eventbrite), Gokul Rajaram [https://substack.com/redirect/98ed64b4-dad7-4c32-94b1-701865b0406f?u@394114] (Caviar), Hamish McKenzie [https://substack.com/redirect/871981a6-886b-43f2-a9b8-1c735713c1be?u@394114] (Substack), Joey Grassia [https://substack.com/redirect/0d06aab5-4ebd-4023-baea-37fcfc491007?u@394114] (Shef), Max Mullen [https://substack.com/redirect/7ca0bef7-0105-44eb-9ded-7cdb19b557ea?u@394114] (Instacart), Michael Horvath [https://substack.com/redirect/568143fb-0448-417f-84b1-734ea2938099?u@394114] (Strava), Nickey Skarstad [https://substack.com/redirect/7086ab8f-34f6-451b-b922-1dcb750dd1bc?u@394114] and Dan McKinley [https://substack.com/redirect/523d9fe6-aa75-4ab1-9abe-8253bd04d503?u@394114] (Etsy), Nikhil Jhunjhnuwala [https://substack.com/redirect/4247613e-8b92-42e8-b961-506d4e63f098?u@394114] (Noom), Rahul Vohra [https://substack.com/redirect/35a6e553-10f1-489e-81d4-09d5ccddc6ae?u@394114] (Superhuman),

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Russel Simmons [https://substack.com/redirect/e65faeea-d581-48cd-bed9-0a1300225308?u@394114] (Yelp), Ryan Hoover [https://substack.com/redirect/f9e11f57-3609-46dd-aa75-a9b9ceab346c?u@394114] (Product Hunt), Sander Daniels [https://substack.com/redirect/25cb343a-0ede-4fd9-974d-cec13b1a2101?u@394114] (Thumbtack), Scott Belsky [https://substack.com/redirect/89f01808-fed5-424d-aa06-c08dd609ea26?u@394114] (Behance), Sriram Krishnan [https://substack.com/redirect/708335d3-0b96-4000-85df-ff48ebebc440?u@394114] (Spotify), Stefan Heinrich Henriquez [https://substack.com/redirect/50b5653b-93df-4728-8f9e-1f5919b2ce2b?u@394114] (TikTok), and Steve Chen

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/9615c082-993e-46a5-8689-e2f21cde272c?u@394114] (YouTube) for sharing your stories with me for this post üôè
How to find your first 1,000 users
Strategy 1: Reach out to friends and colleagues
The easiest and fastest way to find your early users, and a large driver of early growth for about 20% of startups, is to reach out to your friends and former colleagues.
 There‚Äôs little downside to giving this a shot, but just don‚Äôt get discouraged if it doesn‚Äôt bear fruit, as your friends may not be anything like your super-specific who.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Ideal for: Products that most people will find useful (e.g. Reddit, Facebook, Lyft)
Key: Your friends are close to your super-specific-who definition
Takeaway question: Have you asked your friends to try out your product yet?
 Stories that show this tactic in action:
Yelp
‚ÄúInviting people from our network (mostly former coworkers from PayPal) drove our initial users.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: We asked all our network to invite their friends, and being startup people who wanted to help us, they obliged, so two degrees out, we probably got to 1K or so users.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: The takeaway is not to underestimate the power of one‚Äôs personal referral network and to think deeply about the incentive and mechanics.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄîRussel Simmons

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/e65faeea-d581-48cd-bed9-0a1300225308?u@394114], co-founder
Lyft
‚ÄúBefore we launched the Lyft waitlist,¬†we first sent personal email invites to our friends.‚Äù
‚Äî

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Emily Castor Warren [https://substack.com/redirect/4b23e88f-79a5-4c31-98d4-a7be85e30ace?u@394114], early employee
Facebook
‚Äú[Mark] Zuckerberg‚Äôs friends made up most of the 10 first Facebook sign-ups, after which the social network expanded to friends of friends across campus.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Eventually it swept all Ivy League colleges, the nation, and then the world.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
„ÉºBusiness Insider [https://substack.com/redirect/bd472e59-ccad-4e00-8075-cf725c7beaec?u@394114]
Strava
‚ÄúWe started with friends and asked them to invite a few friends. We got to about 100 with direct friends, and then it spread to about 1,000 by the end of the first 12 months by word of mouth.‚Äù
‚ÄîMichael Horvath [https://substack.com/redirect/568143fb-0448-417f-84b1-734ea2938099?u@394114], CEO and co-founder
LinkedIn
‚ÄúReid [Hoffman] and the rest of the founding team all sent invites to our professional contacts on launch day.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: We asked all those folks to try the v1 product and invite their professional contacts.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: In total that was maybe a couple thousand individuals.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: During the first seven days, most of the 12,000-odd people who signed up were either 1st degree (e.g. directly knew someone on the founding team) or 2nd degree (‚Äòfriend of a friend‚Äô of someone on the founding team) connections. So virtually all of the people who signed up in the first week were part of the startup ecosystem (so, predisposed to try out new products) and had a direct or indirect connection to the LinkedIn team (therefore more willing to check out a colleague/friend‚Äôs new project).‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
„ÉºLee Hower [https://substack.com/redirect/c31956c4-e721-4846-90aa-bf2262ab179b?u@394114], founding team, via Quora [https://substack.com/redirect/c33be9a0-25d6-4252-8cff-d5113a6fbff3?u@394114]
Substack
‚ÄúIt all started with Bill Bishop, author of Sinocism [https://substack.com/redirect/2643f574-e9d1-4cc5-8302-8d1251e7bbc6?u@394114], who I knew from my days as a reporter in Hong Kong (and later, a visiting reporter in China).

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: He had been publishing Sinocism as a free newsletter for five years, and I was a reader. In 2017 he started telling his readers he was going to put up a paywall.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: This was around the time that Chris

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: [Best] and I were talking about starting Substack. I asked Bill if he‚Äôd be interested in being Substack‚Äôs first publisher, and he said ‚ÄòSure!‚Äô

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: So we built the first version of the product to suit his needs and iterated from there.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Through suggestions from friends, and friends of friends, I also recruited Kelly Dwyer, formerly of Yahoo Sports and now author of The Second Arrangement [https://substack.com/redirect/a7fc0e18-c3d6-4a6e-9a59-3b6e11c81ba0?u@394114], and Daniel Lavery, one of the founders of The Toast and now author of The Shatner Chatner [https://substack.com/redirect/cf1e004c-047a-4c4a-a115-996788d11115?u@394114]. They were the first three publishers on Substack.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
And from there, I kept asking smart friends, many of whom worked in media, for writer recommendations, and then in each call or meeting with a writer, I‚Äôd ask that writer for more recommendations.‚Äù
‚ÄîHamish McKenzie [https://substack.com/redirect/871981a6-886b-43f2-a9b8-1c735713c1be?u@394114], co-founder
Quora
‚ÄúQuora launched in January 2010 with a user base largely composed of [Adam] D‚ÄôAngelo‚Äôs and [Charlie] Cheever‚Äôs¬†college and high-school friends, meaning there was a lot of early Quora information on the best places to eat in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, where Cheever was raised. But they also built a feature into the site whereby users could invite people, and soon¬†their friends from Facebook were summoning people from other startups, and other entrepreneurs.‚Äù
‚ÄîWired [https://substack.com/redirect/452562ba-36b9-4ec3-ab3e-d9c84dbcbbdd?u@394114]
But be careful‚Äîyour friends may not be the best source of inspiration, as WhatsApp co-founder Jan Koum found:
‚ÄúHe demoed WhatsApp to some friends, but none of them liked it. Moreover, issues like battery draining, crashing of the app, etc. made Koum so disappointed that he lost all hope and started to look for a new job.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
‚ÄîAashish Pahwa [https://substack.com/redirect/9318fd52-5b0a-4fbb-96af-89956bd0ca59?u@394114], via Feedough [https://substack.com/redirect/7f9d1704-c92b-480c-aa5c-e934df95f084?u@394114]
And it doesn‚Äôt always work out, as Patreon co-founders Jack Conte and Sam Yam experienced:
‚ÄúJack obviously had a huge plan to launch to his whole audience. And on top of that, he had this whole network of artists and creators, and we were going to be launching on day one with just millions of fans and artists talking about how you could support them on Patreon.
 So we made a list of like 40 or so creators we knew, people who have local, small followings, folks who I thought, like, ‚ÄòHey, you‚Äôre in the same boat that I‚Äôm in right now; do this, I think this could be valuable to you.‚Äô

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: We made an Excel spreadsheet with those folks, and I found their contact info and reached out to all 40 of them.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
And all 40 of them said no.‚Äù
‚Äî

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Sam Yam [https://substack.com/redirect/a4da0065-ab48-4331-9f08-bea5c1e3f96f?u@394114], co-founder, via How I Built This [https://substack.com/redirect/1db4856b-5545-4925-a950-b5b21a4ddbd2?u@394114]
Strategy 2: Reach out to targeted strangers
The second most common way to acquire your first 1,000 users, important for the early growth of 30% of consumer startups, is to go recruit them directly, either through email, DMs, phone calls, or door to door. Interestingly, this tactic was almost exclusively used by marketplace startups to bootstrap the supply side and rarely used by non-marketplaces. I imagine this is because one unit of supply is worth a lot to a new marketplace, and so the ROI on this manual cold outreach is high enough.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Ideal for: Marketplaces and platforms
Key: Each new user you recruit is highly valuable (e.g. a Cameo celebrity)
 Takeaway question: Would it be worth having someone on your team ping 100+ people directly?
 Here are some stories that illustrate this tactic in action:
Cameo (supply side): DMs
‚ÄúThe founders hired $10/month interns to DM talent on Instagram and Twitter.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: The bet was that they could bring on celebrities and influencers who would message to their audience that they could be booked on Cameo, driving user growth.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
The interns ended up punching above their weight.‚Äù
‚ÄîStefan Heinrich Henriquez [https://substack.com/redirect/50b5653b-93df-4728-8f9e-1f5919b2ce2b?u@394114], early employee
YouTube (supply side): Email
‚ÄúFor the entirety of the summer of 2005, it was a lot of experimentation‚Äîgoing after bloggers, video bloggers, photographers, pets communities, etc. It was a lot of trial and error in guessing what type of content creators were looking and [were] in need of a service like YouTube.‚Äù
‚Äî Steve Chen [https://substack.com/redirect/9615c082-993e-46a5-8689-e2f21cde272c?u@394114], co-founder
Airbnb (supply side): Phone, email
‚ÄúDirect sales was critical to get the first listings on the platform, especially in immature markets without critical mass.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: It enabled us to pick and choose different supply types and build the right mix of homes.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
The local teams were accountable for their market and could themselves decide which supply to acquire, e.g. in which neighborhood, what size of the listing, and price points.‚Äù
‚ÄîGeorg Bauser [https://substack.com/redirect/59cc8d11-e61e-4884-98f9-0da51950e5b4?u@394114], early employee
DoorDash (supply side): Door to door, phone
‚ÄúIn the beginning it was me going door to door to convince restaurants to join. Thinking about how to convince them to join. I don‚Äôt think there was anything else that could be substituted for that.‚Äù
‚Äî

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Tony Xu

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/9c1da3b3-b371-4dcf-a12c-9f1ec6684c39?u@394114], co-founder
Thumbtack (supply side): Email
‚ÄúWe used email marketing to get our first 1,000 users.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: We found email addresses of local service professionals and messaged them letting them know we existed. If they registered with Thumbtack, we would start sending them job leads.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: The number-one thing any local service professional wants is new customers.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: We found new customers for them, notified them via email, and they signed up.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
‚ÄîSander Daniels [https://substack.com/redirect/25cb343a-0ede-4fd9-974d-cec13b1a2101?u@394114], co-founder
Caviar (supply side): Door to door, phone
‚ÄúFor us, for supply growth, it was¬†direct sales/field sales‚Äîno question!‚Äù
‚Äî Gokul Rajaram [https://substack.com/redirect/98ed64b4-dad7-4c32-94b1-701865b0406f?u@394114], early employee
Uber (supply side): Phone
‚ÄúUber Black was initially ops- and phone-driven.¬†

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: They would call limo companies to pitch them.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: A lot of limo companies were sole proprietorships, and the pitch was ‚ÄòWhile you are waiting for trips, we‚Äôll guarantee you a minimum level of income if you keep this app on.‚Äô

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
‚Äù
‚ÄîAndrew Chen [https://substack.com/redirect/4345e607-8ee3-4b17-a7ca-f39648733ed2?u@394114], early growth leader
Musical.ly/TikTok (supply side): DMs, email
‚ÄúSome people say that influencers bring their own demand.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I wouldn‚Äôt blankly state that but rather say that you can offer something unique that money can‚Äôt buy: you will meet a lot of open ears, and influencers might stick around. Influencers, just like any other stakeholders, need to buy into your mission, and you have to be genuine about your interest in building a joint community.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Otherwise you are just another brand/client. Once you create a community with them, they will start telling their fans. 
 So basically: Reach out to specific celebrities/influencers directly -> Celebrities/influencers engage their fans and bring their demand -> Celebrities get $ > They share this with their celebrity/influencer friends > use likeness to promote to more lookalike fans.‚Äù
‚ÄîStefan Heinrich Henriquez [https://substack.com/redirect/50b5653b-93df-4728-8f9e-1f5919b2ce2b?u@394114], early employee
Substack (supply side): Email
‚ÄúI searched for top newsletter writers through old media stories about the most interesting TinyLetters, etc. (which is how I found Griefbacon [https://substack.com/redirect/739fb70e-a59a-40f9-992a-ed111a17f28e?u@394114], one of the original Substacks).

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
The more quality writers we brought on, the more the good word spread about Substack and the quality writers who were using it. And of course, many of those writers‚Äô readers were quality writers themselves. Virtuous cycle.‚Äù
‚ÄîHamish McKenzie [https://substack.com/redirect/871981a6-886b-43f2-a9b8-1c735713c1be?u@394114], co-founder
Udemy (supply side): Door to door, phone
‚ÄúAfter we manually created some successful courses, we had proven the value of teaching a course in the first place.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: We then went to some experts in programming, technology, and entrepreneurship and convinced them to teach courses. These are the same people we talked to six months prior, but this time we had proof that you could be successful on Udemy.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: It was enough to convince two more instructors to join‚ÄîZed Shaw and Bess Ho.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
They were more successful than our previous instructors, so we convinced 5 to 10 more to join that summer.‚Äù
‚Äî Gagan Biyani [https://substack.com/redirect/b3d8f312-048f-42f3-92a6-7582ecdd4dd2?u@394114], co-founder
Nextdoor (supply side): Door to door, phone
‚ÄúBack then, the founding team knew that it would only work if they could find a neighborhood to embrace the idea of a social network for neighborhoods, as well as test it along the way.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Choosing the right neighborhood was essential.
 That neighborhood is known as Lorelei. Nestled close to the Bay on streets shaded by trees, the neighborhood was close-knit and small yet vibrant, with the longest-standing homeowner‚Äôs association in the state of California. The community already had some ways to communicate with each other, which was a promising sign. We reached out to board members of the homeowners association, and they were more than willing to hear us out. After an initial conversation, they invited us to present the concept to more residents at their next board meeting.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄîSarah Leary

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: [https://substack.com/redirect/b45d8547-01c0-4cf0-84bd-b5d33c9faa05?u@394114], co-founder, via Nextdoor

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/7a1be8c0-7b8a-4b9b-8191-5285f84b64c7?u@394114]
Behance (supply side): Email
‚ÄúWe got our first 100 users by contacting the 100 designers and artists we admired most and asked if we could interview them for a blog on productivity in the creative world.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Nearly all of them said yes.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: After asking a series of questions over email, we offered to construct a portfolio on their behalf on Behance, alongside the blog post.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Nobody declined.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: This initiative yielded a v1 of Behance that was jam-packed with an average of about five ‚Äòprojects‚Äô each from 100 top creatives, built the way we wanted (which set the standard for new members).

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: This manual labor was the most important thing we ever did.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: It solved our chicken-or-egg problem.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
‚ÄîScott Belsky [https://substack.com/redirect/89f01808-fed5-424d-aa06-c08dd609ea26?u@394114], founder
Shef (supply side): Intros from friends
‚ÄúWe began by serving immigrant communities in the Bay Area‚Äîallowing them to easily share extremely authentic dishes that couldn‚Äôt be found at local restaurants. What we didn‚Äôt realize at the time was the enormous value in targeting these tight-knit communities, who share many cultural traditions, including food. 
 We found our first shefs by asking where our¬†friends were purchasing their authentic dishes, then onboarded those shefs. They had their favorite neighborhood cooks who they were already ordering from (usually using WhatsApp or WeChat), and many of these folks were also on FB Groups (of that specific immigrant community). We asked for intros, and joined these groups.‚Äù 
‚ÄîJoey Grassia

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/0d06aab5-4ebd-4023-baea-37fcfc491007?u@394114], co-founder
Strategy 3: Go where your target audience hangs out, online or offline
The single most popular (over 50%!), effective, and highest-ROI strategy for finding your first 1,000 users is to find an existing gathering spot for your super-specific who (this is why it‚Äôs important to be very clear and focused about who these people are) and get in front of them there to pitch them.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
This can include niche online forums, events, transit hubs, Hacker News, Product Hunt, college campuses, malls, or even an REI.
 Ideal for: Most products, if a community or meeting point exists
Key: Provide real value to people (vs. just spamming your pitch)
Takeaway question: What are 1-2 places where your super-specific who already gather?
 Stories of this tactic in action:
Netflix: DVD forums (online)
 ‚ÄúWe realized early on the only way to find DVD owners was in the fringe communities of the internet: user groups, bulletin boards, web forums, and all of the other digital watering holes where enthusiasts met up.... Posing as a home theater enthusiast or cinephile, [Corey Bridges] would join the conversation in communities geared toward DVD fanatics and movie buffs, befriend the major players, and slowly, over time, alert the most respected commenters, moderators, and website owners about this great new site called Netflix.¬†

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
We were months from launch, but he was planting seeds that would pay off ... big time.‚Äù
‚Äî

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Marc Randolph [https://substack.com/redirect/034a152a-2eb6-4b45-92da-a666d612ec71?u@394114], via That Will Never Work [https://substack.com/redirect/1080b631-c9d5-4b89-9891-eecd8c1f3142?u@394114]
 Morning Brew: Business classes (offline)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄúThe model we used in our mind was this hub-and-spoke model.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Who are the hubs that have access to all of these spokes‚Äîthe spokes being the people we want reading our newsletter? What we decided was this was professors of business classes or it was presidents of business clubs.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: So Austin and I just pounded the pavement to get into every big business class in Michigan, [every] lecture with 75 to 500 people. We got into all the clubs, and we would basically give our spiel at the beginning....

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
We got a couple thousand people from Michigan.‚Äù
‚Äî Alex Lieberman [https://substack.com/redirect/fba097a9-dbc8-46a9-b426-d2bfcef839d7?u@394114] and Austin Rief [https://substack.com/redirect/ab970f8d-ea45-401b-a871-8dde10d8d5df?u@394114], founders, via How I Built This [https://substack.com/redirect/f6656fa4-b904-4ac0-9359-2c33d9ac630a?u@394114]
Discord: Final Fantasy¬†subreddit (online)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
‚ÄúThe tipping point arrived via Reddit. The team was connected with a member of the¬†Final Fantasy¬†subreddit and asked them if they‚Äôd mention Discord. According to [co-founder Jason] Citron, they posted something along the lines of, ‚ÄòHas anyone ever heard of this new voice over IP app called Discord?‚Äô
 A few Redditors trickled in, checked out the product, and spoke with the development team via the platform. One reported back, ‚ÄòI just talked to the devs, they‚Äôre in there.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: It‚Äôs really cool. Check it out.‚Äô

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
That one comment was a miniature inflection point. More users flowed in, and Discord had figured out a grassroots distribution model.¬†‚Äù
‚ÄîPacky McCormick

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/5018f8b5-c7de-4ab5-b5e9-da3210322481?u@394114], via Not Boring [https://substack.com/redirect/11488309-c919-4e8e-b53c-ba693e588905?u@394114]
Etsy: Craft fairs (offline)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄúWe did something that works and is often overlooked.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: We got off the internet and there was a team out there across the U.S. and Canada attending art/craft shows nearly every weekend. Supporting potential sellers (we would buy them lunch, drop off ‚Äòcraft show kits,‚Äô pass out handmade promos)‚Äîthese were artists/crafters that were influential in the handmade world. We knew if they set up shop on Etsy, and were successful, others would follow.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: The community team went to a different show every single weekend all across the U.S. and Canada. Most sellers I knew did not have any other kind of online presence or activity on other sites.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: „ÉºDanielle Maveal

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/3cfe6ff4-c44f-46c0-a7b0-20cc5a9e00df?u@394114], via Quora [https://substack.com/redirect/b4140d2f-d708-4119-8b67-bbd6bcf51b3a?u@394114]
Etsy: Craftster.org (online)
‚ÄúWe ventured to build a marketplace for this apparently underserved niche, and while doing so we became familiar with Craftster.org (which at the time was another message board consisting of around 100,000 people). We reached out to Craftster‚Äôs founder [Leah Kramer] and suddenly we had an audience with an even larger group of interested sellers.
 By the time we launched the site (roughly two months after conception), we had thousands of sellers excited to register and try it out. The ball started rolling almost immediately (especially since we offered fee-free listing for the first few months while we built a billing system).‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: „ÉºChris Maguire

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/faa99adb-047a-4e4f-9c58-c4ef793a4121?u@394114], co-founder, via Quora [https://substack.com/redirect/4b24062c-2757-4c8e-99ef-72fa8a35d700?u@394114]
Behance: StumbleUpon, Reddit, Pinterest (online)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄúFor our first 1,000 users, there were a few hacks I found especially helpful in this phase.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
One was using sites like StumbleUpon, Reddit, NotCot, and others (and eventually Pinterest) that featured great work around the web with a link-back.
 I remember sending tons of ‚ÄòI noticed your work on MySpace/DeviantArt/etc. and thought you‚Äôd enjoy showcasing your work on Behance‚Äô type of emails.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: The more personal these emails were, the better they converted. And I figured, for every great member we had, many of his or her admirers would follow. We have evidence to prove that the majority of new members joined because of someone they admire.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: My simple daily practice was to bring in 10 amazing new members every day. Whether it took a phone call or me building their portfolio for them, we were willing to do whatever it took because we were so convinced by the network effect.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄîScott Belsky

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/89f01808-fed5-424d-aa06-c08dd609ea26?u@394114], founder
Lyft:

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Startup offices (offline)
‚ÄúWe asked everyone on our team to give us their list of contacts at startups,¬†and we contacted them to ask their permission to come by with a free Bi-Rite ice cream sundae drop-off for their employees.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: They basically all said yes, because Bi-Rite is delicious.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
So we arranged a drop-off operation and¬†had teams of staff with insulated bags taking ice cream sundae kits to all of the companies and giving them Lyft credits.‚Äù
‚Äî Emily Castor Warren

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/4b23e88f-79a5-4c31-98d4-a7be85e30ace?u@394114], early employee
Uber: Transit hubs and startup offices (offline)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
‚ÄúThere was a very significant use of street teams¬†early on at Uber. They went to places like the¬†Caltrain station¬†and handed out referral codes. There are stories about how¬†Travis [Kalanick] went to Twitter HQ personally¬†and handed out referral codes.‚Äù
‚Äî

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Andrew Chen [https://substack.com/redirect/4345e607-8ee3-4b17-a7ca-f39648733ed2?u@394114], early growth leader
Dropbox: Hacker News, Digg, Reddit (online)
‚ÄúWe started with the early adopters intentionally‚Äîwho are the people who are actively looking for something like this?

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
They tend to be people who hang out on HN or Reddit. Getting your files on multiple computers was a niche problem. But this audience was a technical audience; most of them were carrying around a thumb drive. A lot of that community struggled with that problem.‚Äù
‚ÄîDrew Houston [https://substack.com/redirect/f0f61504-a396-4e3a-ad5b-581ce4f4af42?u@394114], co-founder, via How I Built This [https://substack.com/redirect/dbc5c5c6-959c-4d93-82ee-1eee77bcb470?u@394114]
‚ÄúThe HN post did great‚Äîit stayed at the top of HN for two days (this was in April 2007, when HN was much, much smaller) and led to Paul Graham sending me a cold email (saying to get a co-founder if I wanted to get into Y Combinator, ha). But for me, the Digg post was the first big sign that Dropbox would resonate outside of the very early adopter community.
 The HN post was in April 2007 and the Digg/Reddit posts were in March 2008; we launched publicly/out of closed beta in September 2008. We hit a million sign-ups in May 2009, and it felt like we were celebrating new big numbers (2m, 5m, 10m) every several months after that for a few years.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: „ÉºDrew Houston

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/f0f61504-a396-4e3a-ad5b-581ce4f4af42?u@394114], co-founder
Robinhood: Hacker News (online)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄúThe last thing from our minds when we launched Robinhood, the initial website, was that it would blow up overnight, so we were kind of cavalier in the way we approached it.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: [The website] had a description in very simple language saying, ‚ÄòCommission-free trading, stop paying up to $10 per trade.‚Äô

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: And then there was a button that let you sign up, and then when you signed up, you put in your email, and you would join this wait list where we would actually show you: There‚Äôs this many people ahead of you, this many people behind you.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[‚Ä¶]
I remember distinctly it was a Friday night. We had been working on the wait list in preparation for our press launch, which would have been, I think, the following Wednesday or Thursday. Everyone goes home, and I wake up Saturday morning, and I open up Google Analytics, and I see something like 600 concurrents on our site, which nobody knew about at that point.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I was just like, ‚ÄòWhat‚Äôs going on?

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: This is not normal. Something must be wrong.‚Äô

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Right?
And I‚Äôm looking at the analytics‚ÄîI see a lot of traffic, or the majority of it, coming from Hacker News. And I open up Hacker News, and I see No. 1: ‚ÄòChinese Land Spaceship on the Moon,‚Äô No. 2: ‚ÄòGoogle acquires Boston Dynamics, the Robotics Company,‚Äô and No. 3 was: ‚ÄòRobinhood: Free Stock Trading.‚Äô So, first of all, I was like, ‚ÄòOh man, like, No. 3 on Hacker News? This is sort of like every engineer‚Äôs dream in the Valley, right?‚Äô

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
‚Äù
‚ÄîBusiness Insider [https://substack.com/redirect/f7520976-1303-42ae-9952-21394d6ba0b1?u@394114]
Facebook: Harvard mailing list (online)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄúThe site went viral within Harvard after a message was sent to a mailing list of 300 Harvard students. New users were encouraged to invite friends, which helped build critical mass within that segment. More users within a segment improved the experience for everyone else within that segment.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: „ÉºSean Ellis

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/a258b21d-7d3f-47e0-8922-9d0883928dff?u@394114], growth leader, via Quora [https://substack.com/redirect/ee641e20-2e0c-406e-b820-0958c33fc4eb?u@394114]
WhatsApp: Russian emigrants (offline)
‚ÄúTo get the first users [Jan Koum] reached the Russian emigrant community in San Jose through his friend Alex Fishman. That community became WhatsApp early adopters.‚Äù
‚ÄîJohn Popel [https://substack.com/redirect/cfc9c0f8-3e99-40de-9590-f468447acd19?u@394114], via Reddit [https://substack.com/redirect/ba4080d9-0780-4c29-8828-dc1c0874fa0b?u@394114]
Snap: Malls and high schools (offline)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄúEvan

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[Spiegel]‚Äôs mom tells her niece, who‚Äôs in high school in Orange County‚Äîso this is Evan‚Äôs cousin, who‚Äôs a high schooler in Orange County‚Äîabout this app that Evan is working on, and her niece downloads it and thinks it‚Äôs really cool and starts using it with her friends in high school.... It sweeps through the school, then it turns sweeping through other high schools in Orange County, then it moves up the state, and then it moves into other high schools in Northern California and in Silicon Valley, and the growth takes off. So by December 2011, Snapchat is up to just over 2,000 users. The next month, January, 20,000 users. Couple of months later, in April, 100,000 users.‚Äù
‚ÄîDavid Rosenthal [https://substack.com/redirect/56d3ffbc-f7b5-40d3-b698-c6e512999abd?u@394114], via Acquired [https://substack.com/redirect/8687c964-9932-4323-956a-9d7a15143d89?u@394114]
Tinder: College campuses (offline)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄúIt all started at a launch party we threw (at my parents house, where I grew up, actually) with about 300 students from USC.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
In order to get in, you had to download Tinder. I actually stood at the door and told people they were not allowed in if they did not download the app. I think those were the first few hundred faces we had on the app.
 The following Monday, I went to all the sororities and fraternities at USC. I started with the sororities at the Monday night chapter meetings. I stood in line to make an announcement. My pitch was: ‚ÄòDo any of you have any crushes on anyone at school, and are you too afraid to go up to them and strike up a conversation? Do you have someone in a class you kind of want to get to know but don‚Äôt know if they feel the same way? Are you nervous that someone you like, doesn‚Äôt like you back? Do you feel like you‚Äôre seeing the same people every day and want to see new faces around here?

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Well, now is your chance! You can anonymously swipe on someone and if they feel the same, then it‚Äôs a match! All the cool people are on it. All your crushes are waiting for you.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
You don‚Äôt want to miss out, trust me!!‚Äô
 Next we went to the fraternities, I would run, not walk, from house to house saying the same exact thing: ‚ÄòWho wants to find out who likes you on campus? Who wants to see a ton of new faces? Where are the sorority girls on campus? They are on Tinder. It‚Äôs not creepy, this is the new thing.‚Äô

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I actually remember standing on a piano at some point and hearing a round of applause after a speech I made at a frat.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: People were so excited.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I remember calling Justin, the CMO at the time, and he was counting the downloads for me. It was working.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I replicated this at SMU the next week (because I went there for a year before USC, and still had all my friends there). After SMU was UCLA and UCSB. A week or two later was my University tour in Boston. There are so many colleges in that small little area.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Downloads were skyrocketing.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: All the while, I was creating the ‚ÄòTinder University Program‚Äô. We made it a program so that this exact recipe would take place at every school we picked, even if I could not be there myself.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I would interview people, then choose a few influential students on every campus, send them a box of T-shirts, stickers, keychains, cups, you name it. Basically, a bunch of Tinder swag.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: And it was their job for that semester to be a tinder Brand Ambassador and to make Tinder popular on campus. I would measure their success with the percentage of people that would download the app within a certain area. It was a numbers game.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: The Tinder ambassadors would send me photos of events at every cool bar or club where they ‚Äòhad to download tinder to get in‚Äô.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: It was amazing. Once I felt an area was saturated enough, I would add another university.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I had about 15 universities at a time. It was a domino effect.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: The more people on the app, the more people wanted to be on it.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Total chain reaction.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Next up was finding ambassadors outside of the US in different countries.‚Äù
‚Äî

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Alexa Mateen Abdi

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
[https://substack.com/redirect/cb095926-106b-4e0e-92d8-26cf83a605e8?u@394114], founding team and the head of US expansion
Bumble: College campuses (offline)
 ‚ÄúI kind of had a little bit of a playbook [from Tinder‚Äôs launch].

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I had maybe done it once before. I went right back to SMU, this time decked out in yellow. And I went back into all those sororities and I spoke from the heart. Listen, I have lived through the pain points of male-dominated relationships.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I have felt it. I know what it feels like. And guess what?

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
Every other woman in that sorority house, chances are she‚Äôs felt it too. I‚Äôm speaking from the heart, and I‚Äôm speaking to them about how they can be empowered and they make the first move and they go after what they want.
 And me and my early team members‚Äîthe girls are at my office right now; they‚Äôre still with us‚Äîwe went in there, and we took pizza boxes with stickers on it and offered a piece of pizza to the fraternity boys that would get on [the app]. We wrapped cookies in Bumble stickers. We took all sorts of goodies and we kind of growth-hacked our way to success.‚Äù
‚ÄîWhitney Wolfe Herd [https://substack.com/redirect/3848c083-f760-4cd8-ba5d-069e5e56496a?u@394114], co-founder, via How I Built This [https://substack.com/redirect/c15423fd-1906-4f59-9af6-700a27391243?u@394114]
Wealthfront: Seminars at startup offices (offline)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄúFacebook was about six or 12 months away from IPO.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: A number of employees had sold secondary stock.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: We thought, well, who are the best-connected people in Silicon Valley? It‚Äôs the people who work at the social networks. So we did three or four seminars at Facebook and LinkedIn where we educated people on investment best practices.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: Not Wealthfront, because we wanted to get the engineer as the earliest adopter because we thought they would provide the references to the less well-educated people on investing.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: What we know about engineers is they hate being sold. They‚Äôre like cats; they‚Äôre not like dogs. Salespeople are like dogs: they want to be petted and loved. Engineers do not want to be sold to.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: So we did this beta test, I‚Äôll never forget, with Adam D‚ÄôAngelo of Quora and a few people at Quora, and the beta test we did of the seminar to eight people was 80% education and 20% selling. At the end of the seminar, Adam said, ‚ÄòAndy, you have to decide which one it‚Äôs going to be, because it can‚Äôt be both.‚Äô

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: He was absolutely right. That was the surprise.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: So we went all education, and immediately Facebook and LinkedIn people signed up and then used their networks to start telling their friends.‚Äù

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content:
‚ÄîAndy Rachleff [https://substack.com/redirect/d461e77d-db2e-453c-9935-478da761caee?u@394114], co-founder, via Starting Greatness [https://substack.com/redirect/7fec6d57-dc1d-4b2b-aa52-e43ee6ad6f94?u@394114]
Pinterest: Apple stores (offline)

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: ‚ÄúWe did all kinds of pretty desperate things, honestly.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
content: I used to walk by the Apple Store on the way home.

subject: =?utf-8?q?How_to_kickstart_and_scale_a_consumer_business?= --  =?utf-8?q?=E2=80=94Step_4=3A_Find_your_early_adopters_by_doing_things_tha?= --  =?utf-8?b?dCBkb27igJl0IHNjYWxl?=
